topic.title: Attempt to use Git over ZeroNet
topic.body:
I believe that it would be great if we could host Git repositories on ZeroNet. So I made an attempt. I created a Git remote helper named `git-remote-zeronet` which is modified from `git-remote-testgit.sh`, with the ability to auto sign & publish site after pushing, and accepts URLs like `zeronet::SITE_ADDRESS` as remote address. The site must contain a `git` directory with a bare Git repository inside. I'd prefer creating one site for each repo rather than using optional files to build a GitHub-like site.

This works really well. The only thing you need is enough peers hosting the repo. However, ZeroNet is not for large files, neither is Git for.

Here is an [example](/1xxooZ7s8iDz3u56i5mNQ1XGmwF8Zvnw9/), with details on how to clone such a Git repo and how to set up your own Git repo on ZeroNet. I also made a mirror of the main ZeroNet repo at [here](/1FMH8JKKPMY4ToNYNVVo4bGNJwgh6Abzh/), as another example ðŸ˜…

The next step may be implementing a gitweb-like frontend page with pure JavaScript Git parser. For now, ZeroNet is enough for hosting small projects with Git

> [nofish](#comment_627_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): It's disabled, because it would result in more centralization, would add security problems (if site got compromised all of other sites that using the same resource will be also compromised) and there would be no real benefits from it.

That makes sense. If decentralization is at the top priority, we should not worry too much about duplicated files because that is the way how decentralization works.

Maybe a filesystem that supports compression is a good choice for 0net users.
